column2: the town weathered the Depression. The soil of Ruskin farms is especially adapted to growing tomatoes. There is a large area of muck land underlaid with marl in this region. The marl base allows irrigation of crops without loss of fertilizer
column3: as the marl prevents the fertilizer from washing too deep into the soil. Ruskin is favored with numerous artesian wells. Due to the rapid growth of tomato culture and a cooperative arrangement among Ruskin farmers
column4: the town was again a thriving community. It had a canning plant which employed 65 workers
column5: a community hall
column6: and a modern schoolhouse. As part of an attempt to attract visitors to Ruskin and to celebrate the area's agricultural richness
column7: the community instituted the annual springtime Ruskin Tomato Festival in 1935 where vegetables were displayed and the community's most popular woman was voted as queen. The festival still takes place every year in May.

column1: Ruskin is located in south-central Hillsborough County
column2: on the north side of the Little Manatee River. It is bordered to the north by Apollo Beach and to the east by Sun City Center. U.S. Route 41 passes through the center of town
column3: leading north 10 miles (16 km) to Gibsonton and southwest 20 miles (32 km) to Bradenton. Interstate 75 runs along the eastern edge of Ruskin
column4: with access from Exit 240 (State Road 674/College Avenue). I-75 leads north 16 miles (26 km) to Brandon and south 30 miles (48 km) to Sarasota. Downtown Tampa is 24 miles (39 km) to the north via I-75 and the Selmon Expressway.

column1: The annual BIG DRAW-Ruskin began in 2008 to mark the 100th anniversary of Ruskin as a community whose founders were influenced by the writings and philosophy of John Ruskin. It is inspired by and linked to the international Campaign for Drawing first initiated in Great Britain to honor John Ruskin. THE BIG DRAW-Ruskin celebrated the vision of  Ruskin who believed in drawing as a tool for understanding and knowledge and promoted the importance of the arts in education and community life.

The 2008 Ruskin Community Mural was drawn by artist Michael Parker and The Amazing Community Mural Team. Parker with assistant Dave Bush recruited a community group of Ruskin teens and adults. The intergenerational group engaged in an intense collaboration of research
column3: and discussion of possible ideas. The final design concept was based on John Ruskin's social ideal that human happiness requires the mix of the head
column4: heart and hand. Mural imagery includes references to historic Ruskin
column5: the agricultural and environmentally sensitive setting across the bay from urban centers
column6: development and movement to future possibility. Maynard Clark donated the mural site.

column1: The 2009 Community Mural-in-the-Round Project was coordinated by Josette Urso and the mural was painted on the Mary & Martha House building. Both the 2008 and 2009 projects were commissioned by the SouthShore Arts Council and funded by grants from the John Crawford Fund of the Community Foundation of Greater Sun City Center.
There are several locations in and near Ruskin some of which have been included in the National Register of Historic Places.

column2: the area collectively known as Ruskin remains as a part of unincorporated Hillsborough County. A movement towards incorporation began in late 2004 and early 2005 as mounting opposition to the amount of new developments within the community. Many longtime residents feel that the County Board of Commissioners has ignored repeated requests to slow down the development until proper infrastructure was in place. The Ruskin Incorporation Committee was formed to perform a study on whether it was feasible for the community to become a city in which it found it was. On January 19
column4: HB 759 was filed with the Florida House of Representatives with all county representatives fully supporting the measure. If passed the question will be place on the ballots of the voters within Ruskin and the city would be officially incorporated on April 1
column5: 2007 as a sovereign government. The Bill was not approved and it prevented Ruskin from becoming the first new city within the county in over 80 years. Ruskin is the seat of the South Hillsborough County Government Center and the Hillsborough Community College Ruskin Campus.

column1: Ruskin is also home for the National Weather Service Forecast Office labeled "Tampa Bay Area - Ruskin".  This forecast office is responsible for the area from Levy County in the north to Lee Lee County and extending in as far inland as Sumpter
column3: Hardee
column5: and Highlands Counties.  It also is responsible weather forecasts and severe storm warnings for the western Florida coastal waters from Cedar Key to Bonita Beach and out 60 nautical miles.  This includes Tampa Bay
column6: and Charlotte Harbor.  There is an updated NEXRAD weather radar site featuring dual polarization doppler radar and aviation terminal forecasts are also done at this office.  Additionally
column7: this station is responsible for an extensive network of weather radio sites that blanket the entire forecast area.

column1: === First LEED school in Hillsborough County ===

In 2014 the J. Vince Thompson Elementary School opened in Ruskin. It is the first LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) school in Hillsborough County. LEED is recognizes best building strategies and practices as provides green certification. The campus adjoins Lennard High School and Hillsborough Community College SouthShore campus.
